lexUnit.definition: COD: lacking restraint in spending money or using resources.

sentence.text: I giggle a little as I fetch the little dark blue jacket I bought at the same time : it was rather extravagant to buy both but they seemed to belong together .
If anything , we were too extravagant in the late 1980s when money was rolling in -- we took everything for granted .
Thus a lady will smoke , talk slang , or be extravagant in dress ; and will declare her intention of doing as she likes " .

At a formal dinner party , you have an excuse to be extravagant with the floral decorations .

Many of these headings are cut on the bias to improve the drape of the fabric , but this requires more skill to achieve and is also more extravagant on fabric .

The number of extravagant local authorities would be more than 100 .

He died in 1837 and left all his assets to his nephew , who was very extravagant .

Constructed in wood , brick , stone , ceramic , and bronze , this is a work of extravagant beauty , uniting many ancient art forms .
